intro: Pedicularis spicata var. australis, commonly known as the Australian beard-tongue, is a flowering plant native to southern Australia. It belongs to the family Scrophulariaceae and is characterized by its hairy, glandular stems and showy, two-lipped flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in full sun to partial shade. Its flowers, which range in color from pink to purple, are pollinated primarily by bees and other insects. This variety is known for its adaptability to arid environments and its role in supporting local pollinator populations.
